title: Siddhartha: A Poem of India
prev_sentence: It was true that much of what he had learned from the samanas, that he had learned from Gotama, that he had learned from his father the Brahmin, had remained within in him through this time: a modest life, the joy of thinking, hours in meditation, secret knowledge of his self, the eternal self which is neither body nor awareness.

title: Siddhartha: A Poem of India

question: These people had a faith that was blind, blind was their strength and their [MASK], and that made them deserving of both love and of admiration.

prev_sentence: But him, you shall let run along, my friend, he is no child any more, he knows how to get around.

question: He reported everything, he was able to say everything, even the most embarrassing parts, everything could be said, [MASK] shown, everything he could tell.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: What they had never talked about, he now told him of, of his walk to the city, at that time, of the burning wound, of his envy at the sight of happy fathers, of his knowledge of the foolishness of such wishes, of his futile fight against them.
next_sentence: He presented his wound, also told how he fled today, how he ferried across the water, a childish run-away, willing to walk to the city, how the river had laughed.

question: With her little son, she was travelling by the river; but the boy had soon grown tired, desired to go back home, desired to rest, [MASK] to eat, became disobedient and started whining.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Together with Siddhartha the boy, her son, she had gone on her way due to the news of the near death of Gotama, in simple clothes, on foot.
next_sentence: Kamala often had to take a rest with him, he was accustomed to having his way against her, she had to feed him, had to comfort him, had to scold him.

question: But though the ways led away from the [MASK], their end nevertheless always led back to the self.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: These and other ways he learned to go, a thousand times he left his self, for hours and days he remained in the non-self.
next_sentence: Though Siddhartha fled from the self a thousand times, stayed in nothingness, stayed in the animal, in the stone, the return was inevitable, inescapable was the hour, when he found himself back in the sunshine or in the moonlight, in the shade or in the rain, and was once again his self and Siddhartha, and again felt the agony of the cycle which had been forced upon him.

question: For the most wretched things, he had given them up, for what fades most quickly, for sensual lust, for the good life, for [MASK]!
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: And now, they had abandoned him, none of them was his any more, neither fasting, nor waiting, nor thinking.
next_sentence: His life had indeed been strange.

question: Clothes were brought to him, and shoes, and every day, a servant prepared a [MASK] for him.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Siddhartha thanked and accepted, and lived in the dealers house from now on.
next_sentence: Twice a day, a plentiful meal was served, but Siddhartha only ate once a day, and ate neither meat nor did he drink wine.

question: Nothing is effected by [MASK], there are no daemons.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: This is what fools call magic and of which they think it would be effected by means of the daemons.
next_sentence: Everyone can perform magic, everyone can reach his goals, if he is able to think, if he is able to wait, if he is able to fast."

question: Oh yes, [MASK] times he had experienced such a thing.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: When was there ever a time when he had experienced happiness, felt a true bliss?
next_sentence: In his years as a boy, he has had a taste of it, when he had obtained praise from the Brahmans, he had felt it in his heart:  "There is a path in front of the one who has distinguished himself in the recitation of the holy verses, in the dispute with the learned ones, as an assistant in the offerings."

question: Behind them blew a hot [MASK] of quiet passion, of destructive service, of merciless self-denial.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Once, Samanas had travelled through Siddhartha's town, ascetics on a pilgrimage, three skinny, withered men, neither old nor young, with dusty and bloody shoulders, almost naked, scorched by the sun, surrounded by loneliness, strangers and enemies to the world, strangers and lank jackals in the realm of humans.
next_sentence: In the evening, after the hour of contemplation, Siddhartha spoke to Govinda:  "Early tomorrow morning, my friend, Siddhartha will go to the Samanas.

question: How should he not know love, he, who has discovered all elements of [MASK] existence in their transitoriness, in their meaninglessness, and yet loved people thus much, to use a long, laborious life only to help them, to teach them!
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: I know that I am in agreement with Gotama.
next_sentence: Even with him, even with your great teacher, I prefer the thing over the words, place more importance on his acts and life than on his speeches, more on the gestures of his hand than his opinions.

question: They somehow [MASK] to slip away from me.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: "I've lost them or they me.
next_sentence: The wheel of physical manifestations is turning quickly, Govinda.

question: For many years, he had been without [MASK] and had felt nothing.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Motionless, Siddhartha remained standing there, and for the time of one moment and breath, his heart felt cold, he felt a cold in his chest, as a small animal, a bird or a rabbit, would when seeing how alone he was.
next_sentence: Now, he felt it.

question: All of it together was the flow of events, was the [MASK] of life.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: And everything together, all voices, all goals, all yearning, all suffering, all pleasure, all that was good and evil, all of this together was the world.
next_sentence: And when Siddhartha was listening attentively to this river, this song of a thousand voices, when he neither listened to the suffering nor the laughter, when he did not tie his soul to any particular voice and submerged his self into it, but when he heard them all, perceived the whole, the oneness, then the great song of the thousand voices consisted of a single word, which was Om: the perfection.

question: With his [MASK] closed, he slipped towards death.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: In deep tiredness, he took his arm away from the trunk of the tree and turned a bit, in order to let himself fall straight down, in order to finally drown.
next_sentence: Then, out of remote areas of his soul, out of past times of his now weary life, a sound stirred up.

question: Don't you [MASK] him with your love?
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: But aren't you mistaken in thinking that you wouldn't force him, wouldn't punish him?
next_sentence: Don't you make him feel inferior every day, and don't you make it even harder on him with your kindness and patience?

question: It is [MASK] for one of us to see the other again in this incarnation.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: "Siddhartha," he spoke, "we have become old men.
next_sentence: I see, beloved, that you have found peace.

question: He also [MASK] an end to this, this also died in him.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: He smiled a little --was it really necessary, was it right, was it not as foolish game, that he owned a mango-tree, that he owned a garden?
next_sentence: He rose, bid his farewell to the mango-tree, his farewell to the pleasure-garden.

question: It happened occasionally that someone asked for permission to stay for a night with them to listen to the [MASK].
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: It happened occasionally that a traveller, after having looked at the face of one of the ferrymen, started to tell the story of his life, told about pains, confessed evil things, asked for comfort and advice.
next_sentence: It also happened that curious people came, who had been told that there were two wise men, or sorcerers, or holy men living by that ferry.

question: Behold, once before you have ferried me across this [MASK] in your boat for the immaterial reward of a good deed.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: "I'm not joking, friend.
next_sentence: Thus, do it today as well, and accept my clothes for it."

question: And he remembered how he, a long [MASK] ago, as a young man, had forced his father to let him go to the penitents, how he had bed his farewell to him, how he had gone and had never come back.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: It resembled his father's face, the Brahman.
next_sentence: Had his father not also suffered the same pain for him, which he now suffered for his son?

question: Would you like to give me a kiss for a [MASK]? ''
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: But yes, I can also write poetry.
next_sentence: "I would like to, if I'll like your poem.

question: Astonished, as if he had been the object of a magic [MASK], the monk looked into the ferryman's eyes.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: But, oh Govinda, you did not recognise the sleeping man."
next_sentence: "Are you Siddhartha?"

question: He was open to everything, these [MASK] brought his way.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: He saw them toiling, saw them suffering, and becoming gray for the sake of things which seemed to him to entirely unworthy of this price, for money, for little pleasures, for being slightly honoured, he saw them scolding and insulting each other, he saw them complaining about pain at which a Samana would only smile, and suffering because of deprivations which a Samana would not feel.
next_sentence: Welcome was the merchant who offered him linen for sale, welcome was the debtor who sought another loan, welcome was the beggar who told him for one hour the story of his poverty and who was not half as poor as any given Samana.

question: On all paths of the marvellous grove, [MASK] walked in yellow robes, under the trees they sat here and there, in deep contemplation--or in a conversation about spiritual matters, the shady gardens looked like a city, full of people, bustling like bees.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: At sunrise, they saw with astonishment what a large crowd of believers and curious people had spent the night here.
next_sentence: The majority of the monks went out with their alms-dish, to collect food in town for their lunch, the only meal of the day.

question: Now that it has come, [MASK] me leave.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: When Vasudeva rose from the seat by the bank, when he looked into Siddhartha's eyes and saw the cheerfulness of the knowledge shining in them, he softly touched his shoulder with his hand, in this careful and tender manner, and said:  "I've been waiting for this hour, my dear.
next_sentence: For a long time, I've been waiting for this hour; for a long time, I've been Vasudeva the ferryman.

question: At night, he saw the stars in the sky in their [MASK] positions and the crescent of the moon floating like a boat in the blue.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: He saw the sun rising over the mountains with their forests and setting over the distant beach with its palm-trees.
next_sentence: He saw trees, stars, animals, clouds, rainbows, rocks, herbs, flowers, stream and river, the glistening dew in the bushes in the morning, distant high mountains which were blue and pale, birds sang and bees, wind silverishly blew through the rice-field.

question: He thought these thoughts, listened with a smile to his stomach, [MASK] gratefully to a buzzing bee.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: But today he was young, was a child, the new Siddhartha, and was full of joy.
next_sentence: Cheerfully, he looked into the rushing river, never before he had liked a water so well as this one, never before he had perceived the voice and the parable of the moving water thus strongly and beautifully.

question: Where are you going to, oh [MASK]? ''
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: You've been the guard of my sleep, again I thank you for this, though I wouldn't have required any guard.
next_sentence: "I'm going nowhere.

question: What a wonderful [MASK] had this been!
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Quietly, he spoke the word Om to himself, speaking which he had fallen asleep, and it seemed to him as if his entire long sleep had been nothing but a long meditative recitation of Om, a thinking of Om, a submergence and complete entering into Om, into the nameless, the perfected.
next_sentence: Never before by sleep, he had been thus refreshed, thus renewed, thus rejuvenated!

question: On this day, he reached the large city before the evening, and was happy, for he felt the [MASK] to be among people.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Politely, he petted her cheek, turned away from her and disappeared away from the disappointed woman with light steps into the bamboo-wood.
next_sentence: For a long time, he had lived in the forests, and the straw hut of the ferryman, in which he had slept that night, had been the first roof for a long time he has had over his head.

question: Slowly, he hoped to win him over, by [MASK] patience.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: He did not force him, he did many a chore for him, always picked the best piece of the meal for him.
next_sentence: Rich and happy, he had called himself, when the boy had come to him.

question: Worthless, so it [MASK] to him, worthless and pointless was the way he had been going through life; nothing which was alive, nothing which was in some way delicious or worth keeping he had left in his hands.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Starting up from this dream, he felt encompassed by a deep sadness.
next_sentence: Alone he stood there and empty like a castaway on the shore.

question: Tell me, my [MASK]: you're not taking control of your son's upbringing?
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Not a small one, his pain will be; after all, his heart is proud and hard, people like this have to suffer a lot, err a lot, do much injustice, burden themselves with much sin.
next_sentence: You don't force him?

question: Which father, which teacher had been able to protect him from living his life for himself, from soiling himself with life, from burdening himself with guilt, from drinking the bitter drink for himself, from finding his [MASK] for himself?
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Were his father's religious devotion, his teachers warnings, his own knowledge, his own search able to keep him safe?
next_sentence: Would you think, my dear, anybody might perhaps be spared from taking this path?

question: Both, the thoughts as well as the senses, were pretty things, the ultimate meaning was hidden behind both of them, both had to be listened to, both had to be played with, both neither had to be scorned nor overestimated, from both the secret voices of the innermost [MASK] had to be attentively perceived.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: No, this world of thought was also still on this side, and nothing could be achieved by killing the random self of the senses, if the random self of thoughts and learned knowledge was fattened on the other hand.
next_sentence: He wanted to strive for nothing, except for what the voice commanded him to strive for, dwell on nothing, except where the voice would advise him to do so.

question: It also happened that [MASK] people came, who had been told that there were two wise men, or sorcerers, or holy men living by that ferry.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: It happened occasionally that someone asked for permission to stay for a night with them to listen to the river.
next_sentence: The curious people asked many questions, but they got no answers, and they found neither sorcerers nor wise men, they only found two friendly little old men, who seemed to be mute and to have become a bit strange and gaga.

question: There is little which is still missing in me, oh excellent one: [MASK] clothes, fine shoes, money in my pouch.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: I have already taken off my beard, have combed the hair, have oil in my hair.
next_sentence: You shall know, Siddhartha has set harder goals for himself than such trifles, and he has reached them.

question: Were the [MASK] not creations, created like me and you, subject to time, mortal?
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Was it not the Atman, He, the only one, the singular one?
next_sentence: Was it therefore good, was it right, was it meaningful and the highest occupation to make offerings to the gods?

question: This was the great vomiting he had longed for: death, the [MASK] to bits of the form he hated!
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: There was nothing left for him, except to annihilate himself, except to smash the failure into which he had shaped his life, to throw it away, before the feet of mockingly laughing gods.
next_sentence: Let him be food for fishes, this dog Siddhartha, this lunatic, this depraved and rotten body, this weakened and abused soul!

question: He looked around, as if he was seeing the [MASK] for the first time.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: I want to learn from myself, want to be my student, want to get to know myself, the secret of Siddhartha."
next_sentence: Beautiful was the world, colourful was the world, strange and mysterious was the world!

question: It has not come to you by means of [MASK]!
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: It has come to you in the course of your own search, on your own path, through thoughts, through meditation, through realizations, through enlightenment.
next_sentence: And--thus is my thought, oh exalted one,--nobody will obtain salvation by means of teachings!

question: And in the night's last hour, before the day began, he returned, stepped into the room, saw the young [MASK] standing there, who seemed tall and like a stranger to him.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: And he came back hour after hour, silently, he looked into the chamber, saw him standing in the same place, filled his heart with anger, filled his heart with unrest, filled his heart with anguish, filled it with sadness.
next_sentence: "Siddhartha," he spoke, "what are you waiting for?"

question: Kamala often had to take a rest with him, he was accustomed to having his [MASK] against her, she had to feed him, had to comfort him, had to scold him.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: With her little son, she was travelling by the river; but the boy had soon grown tired, desired to go back home, desired to rest, desired to eat, became disobedient and started whining.
next_sentence: He did not comprehend why he had to go on this exhausting and sad pilgrimage with his mother, to an unknown place, to a stranger, who was holy and about to die.

question: Siddhartha does nothing, he waits, he thinks, he fasts, but he passes through the things of the world like a rock through water, without doing anything, without stirring; he is drawn, he lets himself [MASK].
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: This is how it is when Siddhartha has a goal, a resolution.
next_sentence: His goal attracts him, because he doesn't let anything enter his soul which might oppose the goal.

question: Commemorate me, when you'll [MASK] offerings to the gods . ''
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: Let your friendship be my reward.
next_sentence: Smiling, they parted.

question: Just slowly and imperceptibly, as the harvest seasons and rainy seasons passed by, his mockery had become more tired, his superiority had become more [MASK].
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: When Kamaswami was ailing, when he was annoyed, when he felt insulted, when he was vexed by his worries as a merchant, Siddhartha had always watched it with mockery.
next_sentence: Just slowly, among his growing riches, Siddhartha had assumed something of the childlike people's ways for himself, something of their childlikeness and of their fearfulness.

question: For a long time, he had lived in the forests, and the straw [MASK] of the ferryman, in which he had slept that night, had been the first roof for a long time he has had over his head.
title: Siddhartha
prev_sentence: On this day, he reached the large city before the evening, and was happy, for he felt the need to be among people.
next_sentence: Before the city, in a beautifully fenced grove, the traveller came across a small group of servants, both male and female, carrying baskets.
